elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1. EXT. SNOWFIELD
FX: TARDIS MATERIALISES, DOOR OPENS. FOOTSTEPS ONTO SNOW.
(STEPPING OUT) I’d fasten up those anoraks, if I were you.
(COLD) Professor! Couldn’t we have found somewhere warmer?
(ALSO COLD) Yeah, like Marbella?
Botswana?
Southport?
Southport?
(SHIVERS) Southport would be warmer than this.
Now, now, the Alaskan scenery has its own wild charms. (FX:
TARDIS DOOR) And it’s 1934, so the ice is more secure than in your era, Mister Hex.
Yes, Doctor. Alaska. Wild. Charming. Cold.
Well — not Alaska precisely, rather an island off its Northern coast. An island that wasn’t here four years, three months and Six days ago. Hence the appeal of coming here.
Yeah. Hugely appealing.
It wasn’t here? What is it? Volcanic?
Hard to tell, with the bedrock so covered in snow and ice...
Yeah. Mind we don’t lose the TARDIS, seeing as it still thinks white is this season’s colour.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 4
. But I don’t think so.
Then how did it get here? I presume it didn’t just drop out of the sky. Or did it?
No, I don’t think that’s it either. Look at the formations in the cliff face above...
(SEEING CORBIN) Oh now, that’s interesting.
Yeah. More snow and ice.
Look up, dummy.
Hey, there’s a man!
Precisely. Watching us. — (CALLING) Hello up there!
(DISTANT, RUNNING OFF) Nooo!!!
He didn’t like the look of us.
More to the point, he sounded frightened.
Which means we’re going after him?
Fear, as the mystics used to say, is the first step towards
revelation. — Come on!
FX: FOOTSTEPS HURRYING OFF THROUGH SNOW. CROSSFADE TO:
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 5
SCENE 2: EXT. TOP OF ICE CLIFF
FX: COLD WIND. THREESOME CLAMBERING TO TOP OF SNOWY CLIFF.
(EFFORT) Ah — good — this is the top!
(GASPING) What a disappointment. I was hoping there’d be at least another thousand feet. For the workout, you know?
Any sign of that bloke, Doctor?
No, but... (DROPPING HEAVY HINT) .. why don’t we wander over to those rocks?
Yeah, I get you...
(FX: A FEW STEPS IN THE SNOW. CORBIN POPPING UP FROM BEHIND ROCKS. )
No! Keep away!
Doctor, he’s got a gun!
It doesn’t look like a gun.
Who are you? You — you’re not — [Whytecrag’s people?I]
Friends, that’s who we are.
Friends? Whose friends? Whytecrag’s? You’re Whytecrag’s team? You got here? You got here!
Yes, yes, we got here.
Then tell me... “How many lurkers dream in the vault?”
(SOTTO) Lurkers? Vault?
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL)
How many?!?
We're starting with the easy questions, right?
“How tall stands the fourth dreamer?” How tall?
Do I get a clue?
You’re not with Whytecrag.
No, but we are friends.
Page 6
No friends here. Terrors, more like! I opened the doorway,
just for a second! And I won’t see it opened again!
TO RUN OFF)
(GRABBING HIM) Not so fast, buster. —
(FX: MAKES
(STRUGGLING) Terrors from within! Terrors, in the black,
bottomless eye of the Ancient Ones!
(STRUGGLING) All we want to do is talk. —
Get — off me!!! (FX: WHACKS ACE WITH THE BUTT OF HIS ‘GUN’)
Aow!
I’m sorry! (FX: RUNNING) So sorry
Ace, you alright?
I’m fine. Whacked me in the ribs with his gun.
I said, it isn’t a gun.
Hey, he’s left it behind. Looks more like a frozen
umbrella.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 7
An “umbrella” made from the hardest crystal.
You what?
And these spikes on the end amount to more than broken spokes. I should like to talk some more to that fellow.
Great. Well, he went thataway.
Come along.
FX: FOOTSTEPS HURRYING OFF THROUGH SNOW. CROSSFADE TO:
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 8
SCENE 3: EXT. ICY RAVINE
(FX: FADE UP. ICY WIND MORE SUBDUED. FOOTSTEPS OF DOCTOR &
APPROACHING. )
We've lost those tracks again.
Yes, our quarry seems to know his way around this landscape.
I’ll just bet he had a better idea how to get out of this ravine than we do.
FX: A BURST OF AUTOMATIC GUNFIRE FROM ABOVE.
Look out!
FX: BULLETS SMACKING OFF SNOW AND ROCK NEARBY.
(CALLING FROM ABOVE) Cease fire! — Who’s that down there?!
(CALLING UP) Eh... friends!
Doctor — those guys up there really do have —
Guns? I noticed.
(CALLING DOWN) Come on up then, “friends”!
(TO ACE) We really gonna do as he says?
I’m counting half-a-dozen semi-automatic reasons to do exactly as he says. (MOVING OFF) Come on.
FX: CROSSFADE TO:
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 9
SCENE 4: EXT. ABOVE RAVINE
FX: FADE UP.
Here they come now, sir.
I can see that, Mr Slade. (ALOUD) Friends!
(APPROACHING) Yeah, don’t overdo it, mate.
(STOPPING, TO WHYTECRAG) Good afternoon. I wonder, could you tell us —
Who are you? What are you doing here?
My men being armed, I get to ask first.
Fair enough.
I’m the Doctor.
What, from the Institute?
Institute?
You don’t know about the Institute?
Why don’t you tell me about the Institute?
I’m asking the questions! Are you with Corbin’s lot? I heard he picked up a Doctor in Nova Scotia...
The Doctor is who I am. These are my assistants. Miss McShane and Nurse Schofield.
Dr McShane. Pleased to meet you.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 10
Yeah, me an’ all.
(DISTASTE) A male nurse. Remarkable. (BEAT) I’m Emerson Whytecrag. As you’ll know, if you’re with Corbin.
Of course. He warned us you were an imposing figure.
I haven’t even begun to impose myself. Now, tell me: [How many-—? ]
It’s time you answered a question or two. For starters... how many lurkers dream in the vault?
Why not? — Three dream in the vault, the fourth elsewhere.
And how tall stands the fourth?
Tall as a man, of course. — Corbin told you something, then.
Nurse Schofield, will you pass the... thank you. He also entrusted this to our care. — You do know what it is?
The crystal key! - They haven’t missed this at the Institute?
Not so far as I’m aware.
It’s all so near, all of a sudden. You’ve been to the doorway?
Not yet.
But you know how to find it? Corbin’s last radio message suggested the text was correct about the route.
Well... it is.
Well, then — lead the way!
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 11
BEAT
(SOTTO) Doctor...!
It was... that way! .. I think...
FX: RATCHET OF SLADE’S RIFLE.
After you.
FX: MANY FEET TRAMPING OFF THROUGH SNOW. CROSSFADE TO:
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 5: EXT. SNOWFIELD
FX: FADE UP MANY FEET TRAMPING THROUGH SNOW.
(TRUDGING, SOTTO) Doctor...
(TRUDGING, SOTTO) Yes, Hex?
(TRUDGING, SOTTO) We are just walking through the middle of nowhere in no clear direction, aren’t we?
(TRUDGING, SOTTO) Not at all. We’re following my best estimate of the direction that other fellow must have gone in.
(TRUDGING, SOTTO) Nice to know we know what we’re doing.
(TRUDGING, SOTTO) Of course, it is a very rough estimate.
(CALLING FROM OFF) Doctor! Halt!
(STOPPING) Mr Whytecrag.
(WALKING OVER TO DOCTOR) I’ve been checking our direction against the text. We’re a good nine degrees out.
The text?
The great and sacred text. (FX: FLICKING THROUGH PAGES OF
VOLUME) “The co-ordinates inscribed in my mind by monstrous dreams and the position of the stars...”
What is that volume you’re carrying-?
(FX: SNAPPING VOLUME SHUT) The sacred text is not for the eyes of the hired help! Take us where Corbin took you, or — (CUT
(RUNNING UP) Sir! Down there, in the valley! A field of mist!
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 13

Yes, yes. What is it the text says? (FX: FLICKING PAGES) “There in the mists of the valley lay the border between Arctic sunlight and that arcane, abyssmal obscurity amid which the Ancient ones slumbered.” (FX: SNAPPING BOOK SHUT) So, Doctor... we’re not so far off course, after all. Why don’t you and your colleagues lead the way down?
Move!
FX: ALL TRUDGE OFF. CROSSFADE TO:
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 14
SCENE 6: EXT. FIELD OF MIST
FX: FADE UP. STRANGE LOW, EERIE WIND. TRUDGING FOOTSTEPS.
(WALKING) That book of yours, Whytecrag, was certainly spot as far as the obscurity down here.
(WALKING) Yes, a perpetual freezing mist generated by the place itself.
(WALKING) What ‘place’ would that be, then?
(WALKING) We should see before long.
(WALKING) I’1l settle for seeing the ends of me fingers.
(CALLING FROM OFF) Sir! Ahead of you! Sir!
(RUNNING OVER) What is it, Slade?
Ice! A massive pillar of ice!
More like a frozen fountain. Only ten times as high.
Hold on — there’s things in the ice... aren’t there?
I need torches. Here! And here!
BEAT
Saints preserve us...
Whatever did this preserving, it wasn’t your saints.
I know these men. The bulk of Corbin’s team. Frozen solid.
Yeah, look at their faces-?
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 15
Terror. That’s what I’m seeing there.
Mister Slade — compose yourself. (ALOUD) We’re moving on. The target can only be —
Hey, the mist’s clearing. I can see something. Can’t judge the distance, mind. A mountain-?
No. Some other structure.
It’s a building. A building the size of St Paul’s!
More than three times the size. According to the Institute’s
measurements. (ALOUD) On! On! We move on!
FX: ALL RUSH ON. CROSSFADE TO
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 7: EXT. CITADEL
FX: FADE UP. FOOTSTEPS ADVANCING, THEN STOPPING.
(AWED) Here. The citadel. Exactly as the text has it!
Doctor, is that a door-?
Yes. A door in need of a key.
The frozen umbrella!
Precisely.
Beyond this door, Doctor, waits the world’s salvation. And I am the man to bring the world that salvation!
You sure that sixty-foot high door is big enough for your head to fit through?
My, you’re a witty young man, aren’t you? Slade —
(STEPPING FORWARD) Sir.
Alright, I was only yanking your [chain] — (FX: HEX HIT IN STOMACH.) Oof!
Oi, leave him be! (HELPING HEX UP) You alright, Hex?
(GASPING) Well, that took the wind right out of me — sails.
Here’s a witticism of my own, Nurse Schofield. Why don’t you open the door?
What-?
Slade — give him the key.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 17
(STEPPING FORWARD) I should like to volunteer.
(TO WHYTECRAG) Sir-?
Very well.
(TAKING KEY) Thank you, Mr Slade.
(SOTTO) Doctor, you sure about this-?
There’s just one thing puzzles me, Mr Whytecrag. The door is immense. Yet that... orifice there, if that’s the lock...
(REALISATION) It’s human height. Why’s it human height?
Open the door, Doctor. And the mysteries of this place will
begin to resolve themselves.
(FX: MUFFLED, FROM BEHIND CITADEL WALLS, A DISTANT ANIMALISTIC SOUND, ALMOST LIKE A DISTORTED WHALE-CRY. )
What was that?
Something beyond the door. Something deep inside.
FX: GUNSHOT FIRED IN AIR, SLIGHTLY OFF.
(APPROACHING) The dreamers! The dreamers in the vault!
Doctor — over there!
Yeah, the feller who dropped the key.
Get back! Get back or I’1l shoot!
Corbin-?
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 18
Back, or you’re dead! Dead as my party! Dead as my men!
Professor Corbin. Tell me what happened here.

What happened? Why, we barely opened the door before something woke within. From the darkness, it cried out, even as I forced the door shut again. But that cry stirred this mist into a storm, whipping my men off the ground and freezing them to death. If that can happen out here, what might happen inside?
I’m prepared for what might happen inside. Which is why you were to wait for me before opening the door!
Whytecrag — those things in there... they demand sacrifice!
Then sacrifice is what we shall provide. Three times over, if necessary. You see the sacrifices we’ve picked up en route?
Uh-oh.
Astonish me, Corbin. Tell me these three were genuinely part of your expedition.
No. I saw them before, by the north coast. They arrived out of the air, in an English policeman’s box. Only white...
Military police. I thought as much. — Slade, move all three towards the door.
You heard him! Move!
Alright, alright!
(TO WHYTECRAG) I told you, Whytecrag — I want all of us away from here. (BEAT) I’11 shoot!
Oh, Corbin. We both know you don’t have it in you.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 19
I.. I don’t want to.. but I.. I know the killing you have in mind and it...
(SOTTO) Ace, Hex — (ALOUD, RUNNING) .. run!
(RUNNING) With you all the way-!
No! Stop them! They have the key!
FX: CROSSFADE TO:
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 8: EXT. SNOWFIELD/GLACIER
FX: FADE UP. DOCTOR, ACE AND HEX RUNNING OVER SNOW.
(RUNNING) Clear of that mist, at last!
(RUNNING) Lovely view, isn’t it?
(RUNNING TO STOP) Oh no-!
A glacier to traverse. This is far from ideal!
(FX: RIFLE SHOTS NEARBY, BULLETS RICOCHETING OFF NEARBY ROCKS AND ICE.)
Heads!
Today gets better and better. We need to get across this thing, and quick!
You’re mad — we need, I dunno, crampons and that!
We'll be fine. (STEPPING OUT ONTO ICE) Just watch your — [step!] (STOPPING SHORT) Oh no.
Problem?
No, it’s just there’s a crevasse here that’d make Cheddar Gorge feel inadequate.
Watch yourself, Ace.
(STEPPING FORWARD WARILY) It’s alright. There must be some way around it —
(FX: RIFLE SHOTS FROM NOT SO FAR AWAY, BULLETS RICOCHETING
NEARBY. )
They don’t give up, do they?
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 21
(STEPPING GINGERLY) You’re not wrong —
(ALARM) Ace, watch that edge!
What ed-[ge]? (SLIPPING, FALLING) Ahhhhh!!!
BEAT
Ace-?
She’s gone. (CALLING INTO CREVASSE) Ace? Ace?
(FX: ECHO — SHE’S SOME WAY BELOW) Down here!
Oh, what have you done now-?
It’s alright, I’ve not broken anything. There’s a ledge.
Well, can you climb back out?
I’m not on the ledge. I’m hanging off it. By my fingertips.
Oh, Ace...
Reckon I’m gonna have to let go. How far down do you reckon it goes?
(TO HEX) Take the key, Mister Hex. I’m going down.
You’re kidding. (BEAT) I’1ll do it.
No. I’ve done this sort of thing before.
You have?
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 22
Yes. (CLIMBING OVER LIP OF CREVASSE) Not very skilfully, I must admit...
Doctor — don’t! No sense in the both of us plummetting to our deaths. —
(FX: DOCTOR’S VOICE RECEDING AS HE CLIMBS DOWN ICE WALL.) Just hold on to that ledge and do not move! (SOTTO) Ibiza really would have been easier...
(CALLING AFTER) Watch yourself, Doctor!
FX: REVOLVER BEING COCKED BESIDE HEX’S EAR.
Quiet there, young fellow.
Oh, L's. you.
Just concentrate on handing over that key. — Take it, Mr. Slade.
(TAKING IT) Sir.
And pass me one of those hand grenades.
No. No, you can’t-!
FX: CROSS TO:
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 9: EXT. INSIDE CREVASSE
(FX: DOCTOR CLIMBING DOWN ICE WALL, SHARDS OF ICE SLIPPING AWAY FROM UNDER HIM. ECHO TO ALL VOICES. )
Careful, Doctor!
If I can just get to this... ledge... above you... and you can catch my arm.. perhaps we can...
Doctor! Up there! Look!
OFF) Pleasant journey, Doctor! (THROWS GRENADE
FX: HAND GRENADE RATTLING DOWN WALLS OF ICE CREVASSE.
It’s a grenade!
Duck, Ace! [Duck-!]
FX: EXPLOSION! BROKEN ICE CASCADING DOWN WITHIN CREVASSE.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 24
SCENE 10: EXT. GLACIER
(FX: RUMBLE OF COLLAPSING ICE WITHIN CREVASSE SLOWLY DYING AWAY. )
Doctor... Ace...
Alas, such collapses are a risk in this icy landscape.
(LEAPING ON WHYTECRAG) Murderer!
(CHOKING) Slade... Slade!
Get off him!
FX: THUMP WITH RIFLE BUTT, HEX FALLING.
Oof!
Do I shoot him, sir? Sweet to shoot him.
(COUGHING) No... no... He’s of more practical use to us back at the citadel. Up you get, Nurse Schofield.
(RISING, STILL DAZED) Hex.
What’s that?
Me name. Hex.
Very well... Mr ‘Hex’.. come with us.
Or else!
FX: TRUDGING OFF ACROSS ICE. FADE
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 25
SCENE 11: INT. UNDERGROUND CAVE
(FX: FADE UP. ECHOEY ACOUSTIC SUGGESTING WE’RE FAR UNDERGROUND. FINAL ECHOES OF GREAT SUBTERRANEAN LANDSLIDE OF
SETTLING. A MOMENT’S PAUSE AND THEN LUMPS OF ICE BEING
OVER AS ACE SLOWLY, PAINFULLY DIGS HER WAY OUT.)
Ohhh... Doctor? Doctor? Where are you?
FX: HEAVY LUMP OF ICE BEING PUSHED OVER.
Here. No need to shout, Ace. My ears are still ringing.
Let me help you up.
Much appreciated. (HELPED UP) Ahhh...
Where we are now, I couldn’t begin to guess.
A long way underground. Swept clear of the glacier, certainly. Now, you should find a little something handy in the right- hand pocket of your anorak.
Right-hand pocket. Okay. (RUMMAGING) Euggghhh!
No no no, that’s a Yeti claw. Try the left-hand pocket.
RUMMAGING) Ah, gotcha. Torch! (FX: CLICKS TORCH ON
Shine the light in this direction.
Bare rock walls. So?
Yes, but the formation. Doesn’t it strike you as being rather [odd-? ]
(FX: FROM FAR AWAY IN CAVE, DOVEDAY'S CRY, ALTHOUGH SO DISTANT AND STRANGE WE SHOULDN'T BE SURE IT’S A HUMAN VOICE. )
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 26
(DISTANT) Arahhhh — Aaaraahhhh — Arahhh... kahhh... kahhh- rahhhh..!!!
What’s that racket?
Coming from along there somewhere. (STEPPING FORWARD) Let’s see if we can’t track down what’s making it.
I knew you were going to say that.
Watch your feet!
(DISTANT) Kahhh.. Kara! Ara — kuh.. kharaa...!
FX: FOOTSTEPS ON LOOSE ROCK AND ICE. FADE
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 27
SCENE 12: EXT. CITADEL
FX: STRANGE LOW ‘MISTY’ WIND.
(WALKING TO HALT) Here we are again. The door awaits, Nurse Schofield.
(SARCASM) Yeah. Brill.
(APPROACHING) I’m begging you, Whytecrag — don’t put the lad through it!
Come, Professor, where would the pursuit of knowledge be without occasional recourse to a guinea pig? (TO HEX) Take the key, Schofield.
Tell your muscle to train their guns elsewhere first.
We'll see how long your bravado lasts on the other side of that door. Now, Corbin, show him what to do. Or I’ll puta bullet through his head and make you use it.
Give it a rest, will you? (TO CORBIN) Just show me, Prof. Go on.
You.. you slide your hand, your forearm, inside, almost as if it were a glove.
What, like [this-?] (FX: LOW CRYSTALLINE GRINDING.) Aow! It’s... it’s tightening around me arm.
Yes, the key is a living creature. It fits itself around the limb in question. It ought to be easing off a little now...?
Yeah. A bit.
Why don’t you stay with him, Professor? See he completes the procedure properly.
I.. I can’t face it again.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 28
You can face my bullet, if you’d prefer.
Come on, Prof. Stick with me. The stench this lot gives off’s a bit much for standing close to.
(MOVING OFF) The rest of you, behind those rocks there! Now!
FX: FIGURES RUNNING OFF. HEX AND CORBIN STEPPING UP TO GATE.
Now here’s the lock.
Doesn’t look like a lock. Mind, the door doesn’t look like a door. More like a great row of twisted fangs, laid on end.
The culture that produced this architecture created their buildings as... as caterpillars spin cocoons. Vomiting whole cities into being.
That explains a lot about the design work.
You, ah... slot the key in the... um... socket.
Arm included?
I’m afraid so.
Alright, here goes nothing... (FX: LOW, SQUELCHY SOUND.) Ohhh, why do I feel like a vet in a cowshed?
Now, you should feel a bit of a pull...
FX: LOUDER SQUELCH!
A pull? It sucked my whole arm in!
Don’t worry, that’s what’s supposed to happen.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 29
Don’t worry?!
The building is a living thing. It’s evaluating you and the key.
What happens when it reaches a decision? (FX: LOUD SQUELCH! ) OWWWW!!! Twisting me whole arm around...
Yes, the mechanism wasn’t designed for the ball and socket of the human shoulder joint.
FX: SQUELCH!
Now the other way...
It means it’s accepted you.
FX: SQUELCH!
I’m so flattered. How long before it rips me whole arm off? (FX: SQUELCH OF ARM BEING RELEASED.) At last, it’s letting me arm go.
The key should just — slide off.
(SLIDING KEY OFF ARM) Yeah. Is that it, then-?
Hardly.
FX: DOOR BEGINS TO OPEN. RUSTLING HISSING BECOMING A ROAR.
The fangs. They’re pulling apart!
The door is opening. I’m so sorry, Nurse Schofield.
(FX: DOOR OPENING SOUND CEASES. FOR A MOMENT, NO SOUND BUT THE
MURMUR OF THE ICY WIND. )
Nothing. Nothing. The door opened. But nothing happened.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 30
Well, that’s a good thing, right...?
Not necessarily... Now we have to go —
(FROM OFF, TO HIS MEN) Inside! All of you! The way’s clear!
FX: MANY FEET CHARGING FORWARD ON SNOW.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 31
SCENE 13: INT. NEAR MOUTH OF CAVE
(FX: A SHORT WAY OFF, SOUND OF ROCK SCRAPING AWAY AT STONE,
DOVEDAY'S VOICE. FURTHER AWAY, FAINT SOUND OF WAVES ON SHORE. ACE AND DOCTOR'S STEPS APPROACHING, STOPPING. )
(DISTANT) Araka — araka-hi...
Doctor, up ahead...
Shhhh! (WHISPER) Whoever or whatever’s making those sounds is just round the next bend.
(WHISPER) So is what looks like daylight. Don’t you think?
(WHISPER) Hence that peculiar shadow. Let’s ease ourselves around this corner and see what’s at the root of it.
(WHISPER) If it’s got more than one head, I quit.
(WHISPER) (STEPPING FORWARD) Just shine the torch around and -
Ahhra-kah-takkkahhhh...- (SPOOKED) No! No!!! (FX: RUNS OFF)
There it goes! Outside!
It? It was a man.
Only glimpsed one head, so... yeah, I guess. Let’s catch up and confirm the fact.
Wait. Wait! The cavern wall here. Look!
It’s just — I dunno, words?
Words like those he was muttering to himself. Scraped into the cave wall with a sharp-edged stone.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 32
(READING) Ar... kih.. What is it? Eskimo?
No Inuit language, no.
Oh, right. Alien.
More than alien, Ace. This is language that should not be spoken. Language that predates known history. Language of the Old Times. (GRIMLY) Let’s go.
FX: THEIR STEPS HURRYING AWAY. FADE
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 33
SCENE 14. INT. CITADEL ENTRANCEWAY/PASSAGE
(FX: MANY FOOTSTEPS RUNNING ONTO SOLID FLOOR OF INTERIOR. IN THIS, AS IN ALL CITADEL INTERIORS, LOTS OF ECHO, PLUS CONSTANT LOW-LEVEL AMBIENT SOUNDS TO SUGGEST THE ‘BREATHING’ OF THE WALLS. )
Let’s get those flares lit, Slade!
Yes, sir!
FX: SEVERAL HAND-HELD FLARES BEING IGNITED.
Who was that? Slade!
Kinney! Calm down, man!
Look, sir, all around us!
(WALKING FORWARD) Yes, yes! The thousand eyes in the dark!
They’re like.. fish eyes. Growing out of the wall.
I told you, this whole structure is a living thing. Here, among the eyes —
. mouths?
Those curling sockets, they’re a form of ear. Now the text would have it that...
FX: FLICKING THROUGH PAGES.

HEX: Doesn’t look like a lock. Mind, the door doesn’t look like a door. More like a great row of twisted fangs, laid on end.
CORBIN: The culture that produced this architecture created their buildings as... as caterpillars spin cocoons. Vomiting whole cities into being.
HEX: That explains a lot about the design work.
CORBIN: You, ah... slot the key in the... um... socket.
HEX: Arm included?
CORBIN: I’m afraid so.
HEX: Alright, here goes nothing... (FX: LOW, SQUELCHY SOUND.) Ohhh, why do I feel like a vet in a cowshed?
CORBIN: Now, you should feel a bit of a pull...
HEX: A pull? It sucked my whole arm in!
CORBIN: Don’t worry, that’s what’s supposed to happen.
DOCTOR WHO: LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 29
HEX: Don’t worry?!
CORBIN: The building is a living thing. It’s evaluating you and the key.
HEX: What happens when it reaches a decision? (FX: LOUD SQUELCH! ) OWWWW!!! Twisting me whole arm around...
CORBIN: Yes, the mechanism wasn’t designed for the ball and socket of the human shoulder joint.
HEX: Now the other way...
CORBIN: It means it’s accepted you.
HEX: I’m so flattered. How long before it rips me whole arm off? (FX: SQUELCH OF ARM BEING RELEASED.) At last, it’s letting me arm go.
CORBIN: The key should just — slide off.
HEX: (SLIDING KEY OFF ARM) Yeah. Is that it, then-?
CORBIN: Hardly.
HEX: The fangs. They’re pulling apart!
CORBIN: The door is opening. I’m so sorry, Nurse Schofield.
CORBIN: (FX: DOOR OPENING SOUND CEASES. FOR A MOMENT, NO SOUND BUT THE
LOW: MURMUR OF THE ICY WIND. )
CORBIN: Nothing. Nothing. The door opened. But nothing happened.
DOCTOR WHO: LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 30
HEX: Well, that’s a good thing, right...?
CORBIN: Not necessarily... Now we have to go —
WHYTECRAG: (FROM OFF, TO HIS MEN) Inside! All of you! The way’s clear!
DOCTOR WHO: LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 31
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 13: INT. NEAR MOUTH OF CAVE
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: A SHORT WAY OFF, SOUND OF ROCK SCRAPING AWAY AT STONE,
PLUS: DOVEDAY'S VOICE. FURTHER AWAY, FAINT SOUND OF WAVES ON SHORE. ACE AND DOCTOR'S STEPS APPROACHING, STOPPING. )
DOVEDAY: (DISTANT) Araka — araka-hi...
ACE: Doctor, up ahead...
DOCTOR: Shhhh! (WHISPER) Whoever or whatever’s making those sounds is just round the next bend.
ACE: (WHISPER) So is what looks like daylight. Don’t you think?
DOCTOR: (WHISPER) Hence that peculiar shadow. Let’s ease ourselves around this corner and see what’s at the root of it.
ACE: (WHISPER) If it’s got more than one head, I quit.
DOCTOR: (WHISPER) (STEPPING FORWARD) Just shine the torch around and -
DOVEDAY: Ahhra-kah-takkkahhhh...- (SPOOKED) No! No!!! (FX: RUNS OFF)
ACE: There it goes! Outside!
DOCTOR: It? It was a man.
ACE: Only glimpsed one head, so... yeah, I guess. Let’s catch up and confirm the fact.
DOCTOR: Wait. Wait! The cavern wall here. Look!
ACE: It’s just — I dunno, words?
DOCTOR: Words like those he was muttering to himself. Scraped into the cave wall with a sharp-edged stone.
DOCTOR WHO: LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 32
ACE: (READING) Ar... kih.. What is it? Eskimo?
DOCTOR: No Inuit language, no.
ACE: Oh, right. Alien.
DOCTOR: More than alien, Ace. This is language that should not be spoken. Language that predates known history. Language of the Old Times. (GRIMLY) Let’s go.
DOCTOR WHO: LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 33
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 14. INT. CITADEL ENTRANCEWAY/PASSAGE
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: MANY FOOTSTEPS RUNNING ONTO SOLID FLOOR OF INTERIOR. IN THIS, AS IN ALL CITADEL INTERIORS, LOTS OF ECHO, PLUS CONSTANT LOW-LEVEL AMBIENT SOUNDS TO SUGGEST THE ‘BREATHING’ OF THE WALLS. )
WHYTECRAG: Let’s get those flares lit, Slade!
SLADE: Yes, sir!
WHYTECRAG: Who was that? Slade!
SLADE: Kinney! Calm down, man!
KINNEY: Look, sir, all around us!
CORBIN: (WALKING FORWARD) Yes, yes! The thousand eyes in the dark!
HEX: They’re like.. fish eyes. Growing out of the wall.
CORBIN: I told you, this whole structure is a living thing. Here, among the eyes —
HEX: . mouths?
CORBIN: Those curling sockets, they’re a form of ear. Now the text would have it that...
WHY TECRAG: Here we are, Professor. “”.. and the monstrous eyes glowering from the ebon-dark of that cyclopean architecture demanded Sight of the pages of the necromantic text which had led me thus far...” Here you go, Corbin. Show the eyes our sacred text.
DOCTOR WHO: LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 34
HEX: What is that book?
WHYTECRAG: Its contents can roughly be translated as ‘none of your damned business’.
CORBIN: Now... (FX: FLICKING PAGES) “Likewise, the ears of that labyrinthine brain had to hear the arcane incantation of entry...” Let me see, yes... “Mor’eftsa oak-arya!” and, um, “those cacodemoniacal mouths demanded a taste of human blood.”
WHYTECRAG: Blood, yes. Slade, a little cut to this Hex fellow’s hand.
HEX: Get off!
CORBIN: Leave him! My blood’s good enough. And I have only myself to blame for being here. — Knife, Slade!
SLADE: Here...
CORBIN: Thank you. Take the book. Now, I’m hoping the place will be satisfied with just a little - (CUTTING HIMSELF, PAINED) — sip, so to speak.
HEX: Watch yourself, Prof.
CORBIN: This shouldn’t be too dangerous. That’s if I’ve interpreted the... uggghhh... text correctly.
CORBIN: (FX: HISSING, SLIMY SOUND OF FLOOR OPENING: A BIT LIKE
PREVIOUS: EFFECT OF DOOR OPENING. )
SLADE: There, sir — the floor! Opening up!
WHYTECRAG: The entrance to a tunnel! You, lad, take the lead again!
CORBIN: No! Wait!
DOCTOR WHO: LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 35
WHY TECRAG: I’ve waited long enough! And the dreamers have waited centuries more! We’re going! Now!
SLADE: (TO HEX) You heard the man! Get down there!
HEX: Alright, alright, I’m going! (FX: SQUELCHY FOOTSTEPS DESCENDING.) Uuurgh, pretty slimy coming down.
CORBIN: Give the boy some light.
WHYTECRAG: Slade!
SLADE: Sir!
SLADE: (FX: ANOTHER FLARE LIT AND THROWN, BOUNCING AND ROLLING, DOWN PASSAGEWAY. )
WHY TECRAG: Well? What can you see?
HEX: Nothing. The passage just leads into — dark.
WHY TECRAG: Bring the men through, Slade-!
SLADE: Go on then, the lot of yer!
WHY TECRAG: (FOLLOWING) Follow me, Corbin.
CORBIN: (WALKING) This is — this is madness!
WHYTECRAG: Madness, or death — for the unworthy, maybe. For such as myself.. a whole new form of sanity, perhaps. (TO SLADE) All the men through, Slade?
SLADE: Last man coming through now, sir. —
CORBIN: Look! The entranceway!
DOCTOR WHO: LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 36
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: SOUND OF THE OPENING ABOVE CLOSING SWIFTLY WITH THE SAME SORT OF SLIMY SOUND AS IT MADE OPENING. )
HEX: (COMING BACK TO MEET THE OTHERS) Hey, what’s happening?
CORBIN: I warned you, Whytecrag! The place itself has sealed us in!
WHY TECRAG: Then there’s only one way to go, gentlemen!
HEX: Towards that, in other words...
WHY TECRAG: Lead the way, Mr Hex!
HEX: What is that? Professor?
CORBIN: The sound of some alien nightmare. A nightmare we’ll all be
CORBIN: made to share!
CORBIN: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 37

elements.text: PART TWO
INT. PASSAGEWAY
I warned you, Whytecrag! The place itself has sealed us in!
Then there’s only one way to go, gentlemen!
FX: FROM SOMEWHERE FAR BELOW, ANOTHER WEIRD WAILING SOUND.
Towards that, in other words...
Lead the way, Mr Hex!
What is that? Professor?
The sound of some alien nightmare. A nightmare we’ll all be made to share!
FX: THE WAILING SOUND GROWS LOUDER. FADE
SCENE 15: EXT. BEACH
FX: WAVES ROLLING IN. ARCTIC BIRDS IN SKY.
(FX: SCRATCHING PENCIL — HE’S WRITING) “”..and grey roll the waves,
Those dull hues breaking
Into bright white peaks...
Just as.. as sombre souls
Can suddenly break into
A blaze of brightest hope,
Roused by the seagull’s call,
The... um... beauty of the beach’s...” something...
(FX: APPROACHING ON SHINGLE) Hello? — Hello?
“Beach's... bright-lit”.. — What?
Hello there!
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 38
Uh — excuse me, you are, I’m sorry, who?
The Doctor. And this is [Ace-]
Doctor McShane.
Doctors? Oh, I see. I heard we were due one new recruit, at least, after the disappearance of you-know-who. When did you get here?
Oh, just today.
How?
Oh, you-know-how.
We did get a little lost. Found our way into that cave.
Oh yes?
A little scary in there.
You’re telling me.
Been in there yourself, have you?
Never more than a few steps. Before hurrying straight out.
Why? Saw something you didn’t like?
Only, I dare say, in my overactive imagination. I used to write horror tales for a living. So I’m the sort of fellow least well advised to go wandering into such a place.
Then you weren’t wandering around in there a moment ago?
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 39

Oh dear me, no. I’ve been sat here some while, letting my mind drift with the spray off the waves, struggling to fill the pages of my notebook. I’m often seized by a need to scribble down my thoughts. As the only way of making sense of them.
What are you writing? A horror story?
Heaven forbid! Heaven or the Institute, at the very least.
Ah, yes. The Institute. The collection of buildings on the cliff path above, I presume-?
What buildings-? (DOUBLE-TAKE) Oh, yeah!

I’m under strict orders to refocus my slender talent on more upbeat literary endeavours. Whenever I come up with anything particularly lightweight and untroubling, Doctor Gabriel encourages me to read it out to the patients. You’ve met Doctor Gabriel?
Doctor Gabriel? Oh yes, splendid chap.
Chap? I’d scarcely have called her that.
Oh, the Doctor here, he’s very old school. Can’t get used to us women getting in on the act.
Well, if Doctor Gabriel is anything to go by, there ought to be more ladies doing her job. She certainly cured me.
Cured... yet still with the Institute?
Well, I’m showing my gratitude by working for her here as her assistant, a sort of psychiatric factotum. The name’s C.P. Doveday, by the way.
(FAINT RECOGNITION) Doveday?
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 40
Call me C.P., please. It stands for Clarence Penrose, but neither name strikes me as particularly aesthetic.
Oh yes, of course. I’ve read something of yours before, haven’t I?
I hope not. Confronted with my previous literary endeavours, a less liberal head shrinker than Doctor Gabriel might reach for the strait-waistcoat.
Don’t worry, the Doctor here is more interested in expanding minds than shrinking heads.
Quite. Alas, our two heads together have failed to work out the best route from the beach here up to the Institute.
Well, it’s not a place, I suppose, that advertises its presence. Come, I’11 show you the way. Any excuse to give up writing tenth-rate poetry for the day. Follow me.
FX: FOOTSTEPS MOVING AWAY ACROSS SHINGLE.
(UNDER HER BREATH) Doctor...? Sticking out of his pocket there... that isn’t a rock, is it?
You mean like the one that might have scraped out those words
on the cavern wall? Quite conceivably.
FX: SHIFT PERSPECTIVE TO:
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 41
SCENE 16: EXT. TOP OF CLIFF
(FX: BEACH SOUNDS, NOW HEARD FROM MUCH FURTHER AWAY. WHINING OF OLD-FASHIONED SHORT WAVE RADIO. )

Akins on look-out, calling Doctor Gabriel. Look-out calling — Doctor Gabriel? Yes, uh, we have a problem. A couple of strangers just showed up on the beach and made contact with our Mr Doveday. All three now making their way up the cliff. The two newcomers are in close proximity to Doveday, so advise caution. Repeat: advise caution.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 42
SCENE 17: INT. CITADEL — DESCENT TO BONE TUNNEL
(APPROACHING DOWN TUNNEL, TOWARDS REAR) Careful, men — the descent gets steep here!
(WALKING) At least there’s a bit more light down this way, Prof. Where it’s coming from, I don’t know. Seems to be glowing all along the walls.
(WALKING) Yes, some sort of phosphorence. The sort of thing produced by the decay of certain marine animals.
FX: HEX CRUNCHES OVER BONES.
Talking of decaying animals...
FX: REST OF GROUP DRAWING NEAR.
(APPROACHING) What is all this?
Bones. Filling the whole tunnel.
Bones?
Discarded from bygone feasts. (FX: RATTLE OF CORBIN INSPECTING BONES.) This here is plainly walrus. The avian skulls can only be penguin. And this, along here...
(SPOTTING HUMAN SKULL) Oh, wait a minute...
Blue whale, most likely.
Here, Prof... I know a human skull when I see one.
Eskimo, almost certainly.
The detritus from a few fish and Arctic aborigines. This is not what we’re here for. (FX: FLICKING PAGES) Let us return to the text.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 43
Never mind the text, Whytecrag! These bones are a reminder of the power we’re dealing with.
What power?
If it takes a citadel as vast as this to contain such power, Nurse Schofield, how could space possibly be made for it within that head of yours?
You'd be surprised.
Would I? How?
I might just be the person here with the most experience of this sort of thing. Now you’ve gone and murdered my friends, anyhow. So why don’t you give us a look at that precious text of yours?
It would be unbecoming for such a document to be marred by the thumbprints of a scruffy interloper.
Let him see, Whytecrag. It’s unfair not to prepare him.
No!
You and I were supposed to be collaborators. Equals! My opinion in the matter ought to count for at least as much as yours.
You and I, Professor — equals? I confess I had need of a fly on the Institute’s walls. But in no sense could that fly be my equal.
How dare you — in the face of all I have undergone — I ought to tear that damned text to shreds! Give me it!
FX: STRUGGLE BETWEEN WHYTECRAG AND CORBIN.
Get off! Slade — help me!
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 44
There! (THROWING BOOK) Hex — take it!
(CATCHING BOOK) Got it!
Slade!
Give that back!
(TURNING PAGES) Let me just see.. (BEAT; READING) What?!?
Give it — BACK!
FX: SLADE PUNCHES HEX.
Oof!
Leave him, you thug! (BEAT) Are you [alright?]
(WINDED) I’m fine, Prof. Live to fight another day.
(RETURNING BOOK) Here you are, sir. Not too many thumbprints.
I don’t understand, Whytecrag. I thought it was some ancient mystic text you had there.
Mystic, yes. Ancient, not quite.
It’s just some cheesy old horror magazine in a posh binder. “Shuddersome Tales”. What’s that story it was open at? ‘The Icy Something of the Monster Somethings...’
‘In The Icy Citadel Of The Monstrous Gods’. By —
I saw. C.P. Doveday. Who the hell is C.P. Doveday?
At the risk of hyperbole, I'd say he was the most dangerous man on the planet. If man he is.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 45
SCENE 18: INT. INSTITUTE HALLWAY
FX: TICKING CLOCK. DOOR OPENS.
Come in. Just through here.
This looks cosy, Mr Doveday. Quite a contrast to the exterior.
Out there, the place looks like a military bunker. (FX: CLOSES DOOR) But in here, we try to make it a good deal more ‘homey’ for the patients.
And where are the patients?
The work here is rather experimental. Hence the need for a degree of secrecy. Oh, Doctor Gabriel!
(APPROACHING) Hello there, C.P. Brought a couple of new arrivals, I see.
Yes. Two of your colleagues. Doctors McShane and, um...
Hope we’ve not caught you on the hoof dropping in like this.
Not at all. I’m Doctor Freya Gabriel, chief psychiatrist. You sound English. Can I interest you in a cup of tea?
After the morning we’ve had, you bet.
I’d be more interested in a tour of your Institute, secrecy permitting.
I’m sure you would. — (BEAT) Feeling better, C.P.?
Yes, apologies for my funny turn earlier. Don’t know what came over me. I did find myself scribbling another poem on my favourite rock, if you’d like to see-? (FX: NOTEPAD PULLED
DOVEDAY’S POCKET.) It’s not terribly good. Somewhat sentimental.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 46

That’s not a sin in poetry, despite what the bohemians you left behind in New York might say. You should read it to the patients at our next group session. Now — you’re looking a little tired. Why don’t you go and lie down?
I thought —
FREYAs: Yes?
Since Doctor McShane sounded so keen on that cup of tea, I thought I might serve it up in the sun lounge, show off the view from up there.
I really think a nap would be a good idea after such a stressful morning.
All the more reason to have a pleasant afternoon, surely? And it’s not like I’m a patient here, after all.
FREYAs: Of course not.
I’m here to help, of my own free will. And of my own free will, I’d like to take Doctor McShane upstairs to the sun lounge.
If it’s a problem, I...
Please!
Whatever you like, C.P. You know how important it is to me that you feel happy, settled and at home here.
Oh, I do. I haven’t felt more at home anywhere else, in the longest time. — Doctor McShane? The sun lounge is this way?
Thank you.
Take care, Doctor McShane.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 47
(MOVING OFF) I will if you will.
A tour, then, Doctor...?
Yes.
FREYAs: Come with me.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 48
SCENE 19: INT. INSTITUTE CORRIDOR
FX: DOVEDAY AND ACE WALKING ALONG CORRIDOR.
It is lovely in the sun lounge. The view through the windows is a rest cure in itself.
Good, good. There were one or two things I was hoping to ask you about this island...?
(FX: EXTERNAL DOOR OPENS. BIT OF EXTERIOR ACOUSTIC AS AKINS ENTERS AND CLOSES THE DOOR. )
Hello there, Mr Akins. Bracing out there, hmm?
C.P. Where are you off to?
Oh, just upstairs to the sun lounge.
You have company.
Yes, this is Doctor McShane...
Hi.
You have authorisation, C.P.?
Authorisation?
From Doctor Gabriel. Authorisation to go wandering about the place with a complete stranger?
With a Doctor, here to help us. And Doctor Gabriel did authorise our going upstairs, if authorisation were needed.
You’re a Doctor?
Yes.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 49
Prove it.
What do you want me to do? Saw your leg off, or offer a Freudian analysis of your suspicious mind?
Simpler still, why don’t we go to Doctor Gabriel’s office?
You’re being somewhat high-handed for a hospital orderly, Akins.
I’m doing my job. Now come on, ‘Doctor’.
Aow!
Get off her! (STRUGGLING WITH AKINS) I won’t stand by and watch you ill-treat a —
Get offa me, you nut!
(FX: THROWN TO FLOOR.) Oof!
C.P.!
Oh no...
(GETTING UP) You... you hurt my elbow.
I’m sorry. Forgive me. (BEAT) I’m sorry, okay?!?
Idiot!
Come on, C.P. Why don’t you show me that view...?
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 50
SCENE 20: INT. BONE TUNNEL
(FX: HEX, CORBIN, WHYTECRAG, ETC. STRUGGLING THROUGH BONES
TUNNEL. A MUFFLED ROARING, HOWLING SOUND. )
What’s that, Prof? More bad dreams for whatever’s down there?
Dreams? I’m not so sure... (FX: A SHARPER ROAR FROM THE SAME DISTANCE.) It rather sounds as if they might have woken up!
FX: FIERCEST ROAR YET!
They are awake.

Do you realise what that means, Whytecrag? I do. Oh, one can read Doveday’s words upside down and inside out and it still can’t prepare you for.. No. No. I shan’t face it again. I can’t! Hex, come with me. We’re going back!
Calm down.
Should I shoot one of them, sir? To encourage the other, maybe?
Don’t tempt me, Mr Slade.
This is what it comes down to, eh, Whytecrag? Our grand talk of communication with the secret forces of the Universe? Threats from hired bully boys?
Hired soldier, if you don’t mind!
Bloody-minded mercenary, in other words.
Oh, I know all about blood, son. I fought a war when I was younger than you.
Maybe I’ve been around more than you think.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 51
Maybe I ought to take the butt of this rifle and knock some respect into you!
Gentlemen, you can dig trenches and fight it out later. What matters now is finding our way to all that those sweet voices promise.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 52
SCENE 21: INT. RECREATION ROOM
(FX: SLIGHTLY OFF, PATIENTS PLAYING SHUFFLEBOARD — WHACKING
UP AND DOWN A WOODEN TABLE. A FEW CRIES OF ‘OOH’ AND ‘AAAHH’ AND ‘GOOD SHOT’ FROM PATIENTS. )
(ENTERING) And this, Doctor, is our recreation room — where, as you see, today’s main event is shuffleboard.
Ah. Hitting pucks into the far end of the table.
Exactly, that’s how they score. (CALLING TO PATIENTS) Hey, fellas, which team’s winning?
#1: (OFF) We are!
Terribly therapeutic, I’m sure, Doctor Gabriel. I wonder — could we find a quiet spot to have a chat?
Certainly, Doctor, certainly.. but let’s just see how the other team responds.
FX: PUCK WHACKED, FLYING OFF TABLE...
(AS PUCK WHIZZES PAST HIS EAR) Mind!
FX: PUCK CRASHES INTO FURNITURE.
Sorry, Doctor! You have to look out when these boys are
playing.
Evidently.
(FX: ANOTHER PUCK WHACKED CLEAN OFF THE TABLE, SMASHING SOMETHING ON THE FAR SIDE OF THE ROOM.)
Careful, boys!
They’re not deliberately aiming those things at me, are they?
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 53
You’re sounding a little paranoid, Doctor. Maybe you should check in here for a month or two. — (ALOUD) Why don’t a couple
of you fellows help the Doctor to a seat and a glass of water?
No, honestly, I think I’d better... better reunite myself with my companion.
FX: ANOTHER PUCK WHACKED THE DOCTOR’S WAY!
Whoops! Doesn’t look like they want you to go that way either. — Gentlemen, let’s take the Doctor somewhere he can feel a little more comfortable.
#1: Come with us, Doctor.
#2: We know the way.
#1: To the cosiest little padded cell!
Now hold on...
FX: ANOTHER PUCK WHACKED ACROSS THE ROOM.
Get him!
FX: STRUGGLE AS PATIENTS SEIZE DOCTOR.
What — Doctor Gabriel!
That’s right, bring the strait-jacket! Quickly! And gag him if you must!
(STRUGGLING) The lunatics, I see, have taken over the — (GAGGED, MUFFLED) [asylum! ]
Not lunatics, ‘Doctor’, if doctor you are. The sanest of the sane. As for you, we’ll reserve judgement on that. — Take him
to cell number three!
FX: STRUGGLING DOCTOR BEING DRAGGED AWAY.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 54
SCENE 22: INT. BONE TUNNEL
FX: ANOTHER RUMBLING ROAR.
It’s the Song of the Sirens, Whytecrag! Luring us to our destruction!
Nothing that matters to me will be destroyed. I’1l see to it. And nothing opposing me will stand. I’1l see to that too.
I’d better make my stand now, then! (RUSHING) Come on, Hex!
With you, Prof!
Slade!
(BARRING CORBIN’S WAY) No you don’t!
FX: THREE WAY STRUGGLE: CORBIN, SLADE, HEX.
Get off me!
Watch that rifle, Prof! — Get off him, you!
Slade — careful! I don’t want Corbin shot, not yet!
Me shoot him? Look at the old boy! Get off [me-]
FX: RIFLE DISCHARGES ACCIDENTALLY
(SHOT IN LEG) Aahhh!!!
Slade!
(GASPING WITH PAIN) My leg —
I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to —
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 55
It’s alright, Prof, we know. Out of the way, Whytecrag, I’ve got to look at that leg. (BEAT) Whytecrag, you’re in me way!
We have more pressing matters than a little flesh wound. (CALLING OFF) You men, gather arms!
Sir?!?
FX: REST OF MEN STUMBLING FORWARD THROUGH MASS OF BONES.
Leave him, Hex!
That man’s gonna bleed to death if I don’t do something fast!
The Professor’s right, Nurse Schofield. I’d run if I were you.
(RUNNING) Run!
(RUNNING) But that’s towards —
(RUNNING) It’s away from them! Run!
(TO SOLDIERS) Fire at will!
FX: SEVERAL RIFLES FIRING, SOUNDS ECHOING WILDLY.
LURKERS AT SUNLIGHT’S EDGE by Marty Ross (FINAL) Page 56
SCENE 23: INT. SUN LOUNGE
FX: FADE UP. THROUGH GLASS, SEA AGAINST CLIFFS FAR BELOW.
You sure you’re okay, C.P.?
More or less. Tea, Doctor McShane? (FX: POURING TEA WITH
HANDS, RATTLING CROCKERY )
Yeah, sure. Er, you still look a little... shaky?
Oh, yes, I’m spilling it, amn’t I? Sorry!
It’s alright.
